title: June 2022 FQE - Paediatrics
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics (June 2022). Covers MCQs, SAQs, and Clinical Cases.

questions.question: In regards to newborn examination, which of the following statements is CORRECT?

options.text: Initial examination should be performed after one week
Breast hypertrophy is uncommon and when present denotes a problem
The liver is usually not palpable
Imperforate anus is not always visible and may require evidence by gentle insertion of the little finger

questions.explanation: Checking patency of the anus is a critical part of the newborn exam. Initial exam is at birth. Breast hypertrophy is common/normal due to maternal hormones. The liver is usually palpable (1-2cm).
questions.hint: Think about conditions that might be missed on visual inspection alone.

questions.question: Which of the following is a recognized complication of phototherapy?
questions.explanation: Side effects of phototherapy include skin rashes, dehydration, loose stools, hyperthermia, and Bronze Baby Syndrome.
questions.hint: Think about the effect of intense light/heat on the skin.

questions.question: Which of the following reflexes is correctly matched with the appropriate age?
questions.explanation: Moro reflex is present at birth and disappears by 3-6 months. Grasp reflex disappears by 4 months. Extensor plantar (Babinski) becomes flexor by 2 years.
questions.hint: This startle reflex is one of the first to be assessed.

questions.question: What is the most likely cause of diarrhoea in children less than five (5) years according to the World Health Organization?
questions.explanation: Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe dehydrating diarrhea in children under 5 years globally.
questions.hint: There is a vaccine for this virus given at 6 and 10 weeks.

questions.question: Corticosteroids are indicated primarily for which symptom of Acute Rheumatic Fever?
questions.explanation: Steroids (Prednisolone) are reserved for severe carditis (especially with heart failure) to reduce inflammation. Aspirin is used for arthritis.
questions.hint: The most serious manifestation involving the heart.

questions.question: Which of the following is indicated in the management of hemophilia in children?
questions.explanation: Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) contains clotting factors and is used when specific factor concentrates are unavailable. Avoiding aspirin is a precaution, not a treatment 'indication'.
questions.hint: It provides the missing clotting factors.

questions.question: What is the earliest physical sign of rickets in infants?
questions.explanation: Craniotabes (softening of the skull bones) is usually the earliest sign, appearing around 3 months.
questions.hint: Ping-pong ball sensation on the skull.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy's CSF analysis shows: Cloudy appearance, High WBC count (neutrophils), and Low glucose. Which type of meningitis is this?
questions.explanation: Bacterial meningitis is characterized by turbid fluid, high neutrophils, and low glucose (bacteria consume it).
questions.hint: Bacteria eat sugar and cause pus (cloudiness).

questions.question: An unconscious infant with malnutrition has hypoglycemia. What is the correct IV 10% dextrose dose?
questions.explanation: Standard hypoglycemia correction is 2-5ml/kg of 10% Dextrose. In severe malnutrition, 5ml/kg is often cited to ensure adequate correction given low glycogen stores.
questions.hint: The higher end of the 2-5ml/kg range.

questions.question: Anticipated problems in a preterm infant include all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Preterm infants are prone to Anemia, not Polycythemia. Polycythemia is common in SGA or Post-term infants.
questions.hint: Do preterms have too much blood or too little?

questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT a risk factor for mother-to-child transmission of HIV infection?
questions.explanation: Being small for gestational age is not a direct risk factor for transmission itself. High viral load, low CD4, and mixed feeding are major risks.
questions.hint: Which one is a characteristic of the baby rather than the infection/feeding?

questions.question: Tetralogy of Fallot includes the following anatomical defects EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Congestive Heart Failure is a complication/presentation (and rare in TOF), not an anatomical defect. The 4 defects are VSD, Pulmonary Stenosis, Overriding Aorta, and RV Hypertrophy.
questions.hint: One of these is a clinical state, not a structural hole or narrowing.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Rheumatic fever is correct?

options.text: Commonly follows skin infection due to staphylococcal pyogenes
Rheumatic chorea commonly causes permanent disability
Aspirin therapy is effective in rheumatic carditis

questions.explanation: Aspirin is effective for inflammation (arthritis/mild carditis). Rheumatic fever follows Strep throat (not Staph skin infection). Arthritis is non-destructive. Chorea resolves.
questions.hint: Think about the drug used for joint pain and inflammation.

questions.question: With regards to Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), which of the following options is NOT true?
questions.explanation: DKA requires hyperglycemia >11mmol/L. 8mmol/L is not diagnostic of DKA.
questions.hint: What is the threshold for hyperglycemia?

questions.question: Regarding nephrotic syndrome, which statement is true?

options.text: Abdominal ultrasound is the primary diagnostic tool

questions.explanation: Plasmodium malariae causes Quartan Malaria Nephropathy. High protein diet is controversial/avoided. Steroids are the main treatment.
questions.hint: A parasitic infection common in the tropics.

questions.question: Burkitt’s lymphoma:

options.text: Commonly presents with abdominal mass only

questions.explanation: Burkitt's is a B-cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma. In Africa, it classically presents with a jaw mass.
questions.hint: A type of rapid-growing lymphoma associated with EBV.

questions.question: One major side-effect of Diazepam in neonates that makes it contraindicated is:
questions.explanation: Diazepam can cause severe respiratory depression and apnea in neonates.
questions.hint: It can stop the baby from breathing.

questions.question: Jaundice observed soon after birth (less than 24 hours) in a newborn is most likely:
questions.explanation: Jaundice in the first 24 hours is always pathological (usually hemolysis).
questions.hint: Too early to be normal.

questions.question: A 10-year-old from a slum presents with profuse, watery 'rice water' diarrhoea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Rice water stool is the hallmark of Cholera.
questions.hint: Associated with poor sanitation and massive fluid loss.

questions.question: A 4-week-old boy presents with non-bilious, projectile vomiting and a palpable olive mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: These are the classic signs of Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS).
questions.hint: The 'olive' mass is the thickened pylorus.

questions.question: The following are classified as cardinal features of CCF in children under five years EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Sacral edema is rare in children; they tend to have facial edema. The cardinal triad is Tachycardia, Tachypnea, Hepatomegaly.
questions.hint: Children don't usually get swelling in the lower back.

questions.question: In taking a history of a paediatric patient with constipation, which is the LEAST important question?
questions.explanation: Vomiting and distention suggest obstruction. Fever is less specific to functional constipation.
questions.hint: Which symptom points to infection rather than obstruction?

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Hepatitis A is correct?

options.text: It is transmitted through blood transfusion
Has no relationship with sanitary status

questions.explanation: Hep A has a short incubation (2-6 weeks), is fecal-oral (sanitation), and has a vaccine.
questions.hint: Short incubation compared to Hep B.

questions.question: A 4-year-old presents with some dehydration (Plan B). The fluid deficit should be replaced:
questions.explanation: WHO Plan B involves oral rehydration over 4 hours.
questions.hint: Plan B timeframe.

questions.question: With regards to Measles infection, which statement is true?

options.text: Patient is infectious throughout the entire course

questions.explanation: Measles is airborne/droplet. Infectivity is limited (4 days before to 4 days after rash).
questions.hint: How does it spread?

questions.question: The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe:
questions.explanation: Rapid uptake of glucose drives phosphorus into cells, causing dangerous hypophosphatemia.
questions.hint: Low levels of this electrolyte cause muscle weakness and hemolysis.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases has been eradicated globally via immunization?
questions.explanation: Smallpox was eradicated in 1980. Polio is close but not yet globally eradicated.
questions.hint: The only human disease fully eradicated.

questions.question: Persistent Umbilical cord retention beyond which time should prompt consideration of an underlying abnormality?
questions.explanation: Delayed separation is defined as >3 weeks (21 days) to 1 month.
questions.hint: Around one month.

questions.question: Which of the following defines spina bifida occulta?

options.text: Congenital Fusion of the body of vertebrae
Congenital anomaly due to an unclosed posterior vertebral arch

questions.explanation: Defect in the vertebral arch without herniation of contents.
questions.hint: 'Occulta' means hidden.

questions.question: Which is the first permanent tooth to erupt in children?
questions.explanation: The first permanent molars (6-year molars) erupt behind the baby teeth.
questions.hint: Often mistaken for baby teeth because no baby tooth falls out for them to come in.

questions.question: A well-nourished child usually quadruples their birth weight by what age?
questions.explanation: Triples by 1 year, quadruples by 2-2.5 years.
questions.hint: Around 24-30 months.

questions.question: Which is the most commonly used index for assessing nutritional status in growth monitoring?
questions.explanation: Weight-for-Age is the standard measure on the Road-to-Health chart.
questions.hint: Used in the Mother-Child Booklet.

questions.question: The aim of the rehabilitation phase in the treatment of malnutrition is to:
questions.explanation: Stabilization (Phase 1) is for survival/repair. Rehabilitation (Phase 2) is for rapid weight gain.
questions.hint: Restoring weight.

questions.question: Which of the following is the commonest causative organism of pneumonia in children aged 5 years and older?
questions.explanation: Strep pneumoniae remains the most common typical bacterial cause.
questions.hint: Pneumococcus.

questions.question: A seizure is characterized by all of the following features EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Seizures are paroxysmal (sudden), not slow in onset.
questions.hint: It happens suddenly.

questions.question: Delayed closure of the fontanels can be caused by:
questions.explanation: Rickets (Vitamin D deficiency) causes poor bone mineralization and wide/delayed fontanels.
questions.hint: Bone disorder.

questions.question: When taking a pediatric history and conducting a physical examination, which statement is correct?

options.text: You must place the baby on the examination couch
A 24 hour food recall is not important
The child can be allowed to breastfeed during history taking
All children must be examined even if crying loudly

questions.explanation: Keeping the child comfortable (breastfeeding, on lap) aids examination.
questions.hint: Comfort ensures cooperation.

questions.question: With regard to congenital abnormalities, which of the following is incompatible with life?
questions.explanation: Anencephaly (missing brain) is universally fatal.
questions.hint: Major neural tube defect affecting the brain.

questions.question: A 6-year-old with vomiting and dehydration is unconscious with a fruity breath. What is the likely finding?
questions.explanation: Fruity breath + Unconsciousness + Dehydration = Diabetic Ketoacidosis.
questions.hint: Ketones smell fruity.

questions.question: What is the correct compression-to-ventilation ratio for newborn resuscitation?
questions.explanation: Standard neonatal resuscitation ratio is 3 compressions to 1 breath.
questions.hint: Three pushes, one breath.

questions.question: A 6-year-old has Acute Glomerulonephritis. Select the cardinal features and expected lab findings.
questions.explanation: AGN Triad: Hematuria, HTN, Edema. Labs: High ASOT, Low C3.
questions.hint: Nephritic syndrome features.

questions.question: Select the correct features of good breastfeeding attachment.

options.text: More areola visible above than below

questions.explanation: CHIN-MOUTH-LIP-AREOLA. Lip must be OUT.
questions.hint: Recall the 4 signs of attachment.

questions.question: Identify common bacterial causes of Neonatal Sepsis.
questions.explanation: Common pathogens: GBS, E. coli, Staph aureus, Klebsiella.
questions.hint: Birth canal flora and skin flora.

questions.question: A 6-year-old has fever, seizures, stiff neck, and positive Kernig's sign. Select the likely diagnosis and differentials.
questions.explanation: Meningeal signs (stiff neck, Kernig's) rule out simple febrile convulsions.
questions.hint: Signs of meningeal irritation.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of Sickle Cell Crisis?
questions.explanation: The major crises are Painful, Sequestration, Aplastic, and Hemolytic.
questions.hint: Four main types.

questions.question: Select the correct management steps for an Acute Asthmatic Attack in a child.
questions.explanation: Oxygen, Bronchodilators, and Steroids are the triad of asthma management.
questions.hint: Open the airways and reduce inflammation.

questions.question: Which test confirms Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.explanation: Fasting >7.0 or Random >11.1 mmol/L with symptoms is diagnostic.
questions.hint: Threshold for fasting sugar.

questions.question: Classify Pneumonia according to WHO guidelines.
questions.explanation: Current WHO classification: Pneumonia (Fast breathing/Indrawing) vs Severe Pneumonia (Danger signs).
questions.hint: Two main categories.

questions.question: CASE STUDY: A 4-year-old with Severe Acute Malnutrition (Kwashiorkor). Select the correct management principles.

richContent.content:
Case: 4yo, 9kg, Bilateral Pitting Edema, MUAC <11.5cm.
Diagnosis: Kwashiorkor.

options.text: Give rapid IV fluids for dehydration

questions.explanation: Follow WHO 10 Steps. NO rapid IV fluids (heart failure risk). NO Iron in stabilization (sepsis risk).
questions.hint: Stabilization phase rules.
